citations.narrative:
An outdoor enclosure housing 35 fallow deer has multiple areas that require modifications, including:
** The fencing on the bottom of the front gate has multiple broken connections of wire causing sharp protruding ends.
** The fence has an approximately 1 foot high by 2 feet wide gap on the bottom. It is dented towards the inside, appearing
as though an animal has attempted to enter the enclosure from underneath the fence.
** There is a significant amount of broken glass and other materials such as bottles, metal debris and a metal spike in the
enclosure, mainly concentrated on the lefthand side. The licensee stated that after rainfall, the topsoil erodes and exposes
this old debris underneath; the prior owner used this area for waste disposal several years ago. The licensee reports that
the debris is typically removed after rainfall, but available weather records for the area indicate no precipitation since
August 19 (8 days prior). Some of this glass still has sharp edges and points. The licensee stated this debris has not had
a health effect on any of the animals.
Sharp objects such as glass, metal, and wire pose an injury hazard to the animals. Gaps in fencing could allow the deer,
predators, or other animals to enter/exit the enclosure or become entrapped.
The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the animals involved. The
outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from
injury and to contain the animals.
Correct by: September 28, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
An outdoor enclosure housing 35 fallow deer has multiple areas that require modifications, including: 
** The fencing on the bottom of the front gate has multiple broken connections of wire causing sharp protruding ends.  
** The fence has an approximately 1 foot high by 2 feet wide gap on the bottom. It is dented towards the inside, appearing 
as though an animal has attempted to enter the enclosure from underneath the fence.  
** There is a significant amount of broken glass and other materials such as bottles, metal debris and a metal spike in the 
enclosure, mainly concentrated on the lefthand side. The licensee stated that after rainfall, the topsoil erodes and exposes 
this old debris underneath; the prior owner used this area for waste disposal several years ago. The licensee reports that 
the debris is typically removed after rainfall, but available weather records for the area indicate no precipitation since 
August 19 (8 days prior). Some of this glass still has sharp edges and points. The licensee stated this debris has not had 
a health effect on any of the animals. 
 
Sharp objects such as glass, metal, and wire pose an injury hazard to the animals. Gaps in fencing could allow the deer, 
predators, or other animals to enter/exit the enclosure or become entrapped. 
 
The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the animals involved. The 
outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from 
injury and to contain the animals. 
 
Correct by: September 28, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
